**Describe the bug**

```javascript
    // Throw an error if the password selected by the user

          message: 'Your password cannot contain more than three times the symbol `$`.',

```

**Describe the bug**
Every time strapi-plugin-documentation/config/functions/bootstrap.js runs, it will write to full_documentation.json even if no update is created.

**Steps to reproduce the behavior**

1. create a new project with users-permissions and documentation plugin installed 
2. start the server 
3. it should edit full_documentation.json but only changing the`x-generation-date` info

**Expected behavior**
If no update has been made, it should not write to the file

**Screenshots**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20282317/89776024-a110af00-db3b-11ea-81d2-dc29ac5a0109.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20282317/89776120-d3baa780-db3b-11ea-8f24-1de12a8b810d.png)

**Code snippets**
when bootstrap.js runs, it will almost always enter this condition
```js
// strapi-plugin-documentation/config/functions/bootstrap.js: line 101
if (!isMergedDocumentationExists || shouldUpdateFullDoc) {
    // Create the folder
    services.createDocumentationDirectory(documentationPath);
    // Write the file
    fs.writeFileSync(
      path.resolve(documentationPath, 'full_documentation.json'),
      JSON.stringify(fullDoc, null, 2),
      'utf8'
    );
}
```

as caused by checkIfPluginDocNeedsUpdate returning true when checking the "users-permissions" plugin, as it has 2 tags: UsersPermissions - User and UsersPermissions - Role
```js
// strapi-plugin-documentation/config/functions/bootstrap.js: line 38
const needToUpdatePluginDoc = services.checkIfPluginDocNeedsUpdate(plugin);
```

this happens because createDocObject() uses _.merge() which doesnt work if there is a property that contains an array, as it will override the array. Thus only one tag can appear in the object. To fix that the function should be changed to mergeWith that has a customizer for array values
```js
// strapi-plugin-documentation/services/Documentation.js
// from
createDocObject: array => {
    return array.reduce((acc, curr) => _.merge(acc, curr), {});
},

// to 
createDocObject: array => {
    function forArray(objValue, srcValue) {
      if (_.isArray(objValue)) {
        return objValue.concat(srcValue);
      }
    }
    return array.reduce((acc, curr) => _.mergeWith(acc, curr,forArray), {});
},
```

however this raises another error in the `areObjectsEquals()` function as it simply does `return JSON.stringify(obj1) === JSON.stringify(obj2);` to check for equality and will fail if the arrays don't have the exact same order

- Node.js version: v12

- Strapi version: 3.1.3
- Database: MongoDB
- Operating system: Linux

I'm not sure whether you consider this a bug or a feature, but it should be fixed soon anyways.

Right now, the password validation uses `bcrypt.compareSync` - which is quite an expensive operation:
https://github.com/strapi/strapi/blob/97dfde210a793452d70e5b99b5df05899f26de1b/packages/strapi-plugin-users-permissions/services/User.js#L116-L118

Synchronous functions are blocking the event-loop and should be avoided. Hence we should use `bcrypt.compare` and make `validatePassword` return a `Promise`.

I could come up with a pull request if you guys are okay with that change :)

Strapi server fails to start when package.json contains shell parameter syntax, e.g. a script containing `FOO=${BAZ:-foo}`.

Shell parameters could normally be used with npm but Strapi interprets them as JS and throws a syntax error.

```shell
[2018-04-09T05:42:07.122Z] debug Server wasn't able to start properly.
SyntaxError: Missing } in template expression
    at Object.keys.reduce (/private/tmp/test/node_modules/strapi/lib/core/configurations.js:379:38)
    at Array.reduce (<anonymous>)
    at templateConfigurations (/private/tmp/test/node_modules/strapi/lib/core/configurations.js:375:27)
    at Object.keys.reduce (/private/tmp/test/node_modules/strapi/lib/core/configurations.js:377:18)
    at Array.reduce (<anonymous>)
    at templateConfigurations (/private/tmp/test/node_modules/strapi/lib/core/configurations.js:375:27)
    at Object.keys.reduce (/private/tmp/test/node_modules/strapi/lib/core/configurations.js:377:18)
    at Array.reduce (<anonymous>)
    at templateConfigurations (/private/tmp/test/node_modules/strapi/lib/core/configurations.js:375:27)
    at Strapi.module.exports.app (/private/tmp/test/node_modules/strapi/lib/core/configurations.js:94:19)
    at Strapi.load (/private/tmp/test/node_modules/strapi/lib/Strapi.js:197:29)
    at <anonymous>
```

**Steps to reproduce the problem**

1. `> strapi new test` (accept defaults)
1. add the conflicting code to `scripts` in package.json:
`"test": "FOO=${BAZ:-foo} sh -c 'echo $FOO'"`
1. NPM runs the script normally
`> export BAZ=bar`
`> npm test`
`bar`
1. Start Strapi
`> npm start`
`SyntaxError: Missing } in template expression`

**What is the expected behavior?**

Server starts normally.

**Suggested solutions**

Template literals in configuration are ignored if they contain `()` characters indicating a function call.

https://github.com/strapi/strapi/blob/648bf52a3c69b50df14fe69e1625029ab31f093e/packages/strapi/lib/core/configurations.js#L371-L374

They could also be ignored if they contain shell parameter expansion characters: `: = - ` etc. [(Bash docs)](http://wiki.bash-hackers.org/syntax/pe#overview).

I don't think these shell characters would appear when using dynamic configuration as intended.

**Workaround**

Insert an inline comment containg a bracket `` `#(` `` so that Strapi ignores the expression.

e.g.
```js
"scripts": {
    "test": "FOO=${BAZ:-foo`#(`} sh -c 'echo $FOO'"
}
```
